alert.note: Alert for Bristol Bay; Kuskokwim Delta (Alaska) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Special Weather Statement issued December 31 at 7:18PM AKST by NWS Anchorage
info.description: ...STRONG WINDS DEVELOPING WITH SNOW AND BLOWING SNOW CHANGING TO RAIN MONDAY THROUGH WEDNESDAY... A series of strong storm systems moving into the Bering Sea will bring a prolonged period of strong east to southeast winds to much of Bristol Bay and the Kuskokwim Delta between Monday and Wednesday morning. Areas of light snow will spread northward with the first system moving south of the Alaska Peninsula on Monday, with the best potential for accumulating snowfall focused along the coast. Wind gusts near the coast will pick up to between 25 and 40 mph by Monday morning, possibly leading to areas of blowing snow and reduced visibility at times. Temperatures will warm above freezing across Bristol Bay by Monday afternoon, then most the Kuskokwim Delta by Tuesday, ending the threat for blowing snow. A second, much stronger system moving into the Bering Sea will push a strong front into the Southwest Coast between Tuesday and Wednesday. While confidence for the exact timing and strength of this front is lower, there is the potential for even stronger winds to affect parts of the region during this timeframe. Wind gusts will be particularly strong across portions of Bristol Bay, with peak gusts of 50 to 70 mph possible between Tuesday afternoon and Wednesday morning, while gusts as high as 40 to 60 mph will be possible across the Kuskokwim Delta. Communities should prepare for difficult travel conditions through midweek and continue to closely monitor the forecast as details for both upcoming systems become clearer.
